bug.author: maoztamir
bug.summary: Getting scripting error when running streamlit hello example
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h1>Summary</denchmark-h>
Getting an error when running streamlit hello example. <denchmark-h:h1>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>
pip install streamlit streamlit hello getting the following message You can now view your Streamlit app in your browser.
Local URL: <denchmark-link:http://localhost:8501>http://localhost:8501</denchmark-link>
Network URL: <denchmark-link:http://192.168.1.7:8501>http://192.168.1.7:8501</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior:</denchmark-h>
The application should open <denchmark-h:h2>Actual behavior:</denchmark-h>
When opening the browser I am getting the following scripting error charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x9f in position 1081: character maps to <denchmark-h:h2>Is this a regression?</denchmark-h>
That is, did this use to work the way you expected in the past? no <denchmark-h:h1>Debug info</denchmark-h>
Streamlit version: Streamlit, version 0.47.2 Python version: Python 3.6.8 :: Anaconda, Inc. Using Conda OS version: Win 10 Browser version: Chrome Version 77.0.3865.90 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Streamlit version: 0.47.2 Python version: 3.6.2 OS version: Windows 7 SP1 Browser version: Chrome Version 77.0.3865.90 (Official Build) (64-bit) The only commonality here are the streamlit and Chrome versions.

+1 with toltarisa - I get the same error when running from Git Bash on my Windows 10 machine. I tried kgmerk's advice to run from Command Prompt and it does display, albeit with the same funny characters.
Hey create a folder and then create a hello.py inside that folder.In hello.py import streamlit as st and type st.write('Hello, world!').And then run streamlit hello in your console.

Hello, same experience here. Same error via git bash; via the conda cmd prompt, streamlit hello launches the app, but with some character issues: <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71216/66357060-69454380-e93b-11e9-93b1-838df63b4727.png></denchmark-link>

I have a similar problem, but not exactly the same. I get this error message in the browser: File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/streamlit/hello/hello.py", line 18 from future import division, unicode_literals ^ SyntaxError: from future imports must occur at the beginning of the file

Solved my problem above by locating the hello.py file at the address above and moving line 18 (from future import division, unicode_literals) to first line in file. After that, the app loads fine in my browser window.
